vocabURI="http://lod.data-archive.ac.uk/skoshasset/6600dd35-ac34-41ec-88a6-2a8e2aa830bb">YOUTH</keyword>         <topcClas>Higher and further - Education</topcClas>         <topcClas>Primary, pre-primary and secondary - Education</topcClas>         <topcClas>Youth - Social stratification and groupings</topcClas>         <topcClas>Social attitudes and behaviour - Society and culture</topcClas>         <topcClas>Child development and child rearing - Social stratification and groupings</topcClas>         <topcClas>Family life and marriage - Social stratification and groupings</topcClas>       </subject>       <abstract><p>Abstract copyright UK Data Service and data collection copyright owner.</p><i>Background</i>:<br> The <i>Longitudinal Study of Young People in England</i> (LSYPE), also known as <i>Next Steps</i>, commissioned by the Department for Children, Schools and Families (DCSF) (formerly the Department for Education and Skills (DfES)), is a major innovative panel study of young people. The study began in 2004, when its sample of young people were aged between 13 and 14. LSYPE is one of the main information sources for the formation and appraisal of policies relating to young people and will continue to be so for at least the next 10 years. The baseline data will be used to monitor the progress of the cohort group, evaluate the success of policies aimed at this group and provide an evidence base for further policy development. The study brings together data from a wide range of sources and reflects the variety of influences on learning and progression. Annual interviews obtain information from the young person and additional information from a main and second parent interview.<br> <br> <i>Objectives:</i><br> The main objectives of the LSYPE are: <uL><li>to gather evidence about the transitions young people make from secondary and tertiary education or training to economic roles in early adulthood</li><li>to enhance the ability to monitor and evaluate the effects of existing policy and provide a strong information base for future policy development</li><li>to contextualise the implementation of new policies in terms of young people's current lives</li></ul><i>Conduct of the survey</i><br> Fieldwork for the first four waves was carried out by a consortium of contractors, comprising BMRB Social Research, GfK NOP (known as NOP World at the time Wave One of the survey was conducted) and Ipsos MORI (known as MORI at the time of Wave One). Interviews for the first four waves were conducted face-to-face. At Waves Five and Six, fieldwork was carried out by BMRB and GfK NOP only and a mixed mode approach was used; respondents could complete the interview online, over the telephone, or face-to-face as for the previous waves. Also, Wave Five was the first wave at which only the sampled young person was interviewed; previously, at least one of the sampled young person's parents/guardians had also been interviewed. This continued in Wave Six. Validation of the data collected and enhancement of the study at all waves has been undertaken by the National Centre for Social Research (NatCen) for Waves One to Six and by the Department for Education for Wave Seven.<br> <br> <i>Applications for linked data</i><br> The data have been supplemented by linkage to administrative records such as the <i>National Pupil Database</i> (NPD) and other data sources such as geo-demographic data from the 2001 Census.  Due to the potentially disclosive nature of some of these variables, the linked administrative data have not been included on the LSYPE files deposited at the UK Data Archive. Researchers requiring access to the linked administrative files refer to the LSYPE Confidentiality Form deposited with the LSYPE documentation (see Documentation table below) and contact <a href="mailto:team.longitudinal@education.gsi.gov.uk" title="DfE Longitudinal team email enquiries">team.longitudinal@education.gsi.gov.uk</a>. <br> <br> <i>Applications for Index, Household Grid and Activity History data</i>:<br> The LSYPE Index and Household Grid files for Waves 1-4 are held at the UK Data Archive, but are subject to permission-only access. Users who require access to these files should contact the HelpDesk in the first instance. Household Grid, Index and detailed Activity History* data for Waves 5-7 are not held at the Archive and an application for access should be made direct to the Longitudinal Studies Team at the Department for Education (DfE) - see the User Guide and the LSYPE Confidentiality Form (in Documentation table below). The decision to supply data will be made by the DfE on a case-by-case basis.<br> <br> *Categorised information on activity history is contained within the LSYPE Monthly Main Activity file for Waves 4 to 7 (file 'lsype_main_activity_w4-7_nov2011_suppressed'). See Section 5.8 of the User Guide for more information. <br> <br> <i>Latest edition</i>:<br> For the twelfth edition (August 2012), the reduced National Pupil Database (NPD) file was replaced by a new version. The data still cover Key Stage 2 and Key Stage 3 achievement data as at Wave 1 and Key Stage 4 achievement data as at Wave 3, but data have been removed for those respondents who dropped out of the LSYPE study. The accompanying document 'Removing NPD data where LSYPE respondents dropped out of the survey' explains why this has been done. In addition, a new NPD file has also been deposited, covering Key Stage 5 achievement data as at Wave 7. <b>Please note, the reduced NPD file was withdrawn at the depositor's request in January 2015, so is no longer included with the standard LSYPE study</b>.<br> <br> </abstract>       <abstract><B>Main Topics</B>:<br>Questionnaires for Waves One to Four gathered information on:<ul><li>the young person's family background </li><li> parental socio-economic status</li><li>personal characteristics</li><li>attitudes, experiences and behaviours</li><li>attainment in education</li><li>parental employment</li><li>income and family environment as well as local deprivation</li><li>the school(s) the young person attends/has attended</li><li>the young person's post-16 plans</li></ul>The questionnaire for Waves Five, Six and Seven consisted of two modules:<ul><li>Household Information Module: included questions on the young person's household situation details of any persons living with them</li><li>Young Person Module: topics included demographics, attitudes to local area, activity history and current activity, jobs and training, qualifications being studied, higher education, attitudes to work and debt, childcare and caring responsibilities, young people Not in Education Employment or Training (NEET), Apprenticeships, information, advice and guidance, risk behaviours, relationships and sexuality, and own children.</li></ul>The additional 'Monthly Main Activity' dataset takes responses to the Activity History section of the questionnaire at Waves Four to Seven and synthesises this information into variables that represent a monthly time series running from September 2006 (two months after the respondents completed compulsory education) until May 2010 (the first month of interviews for Wave Seven). For each of the 45 months in this period, this file contains the respondent's derived 'main' activity which is classified as one of Education, Employment, Apprenticeship/Training or Unemployed/Inactive (NEET).<br> <br> In order to deal with the large number of variables in the study, the dataset has been split into more manageable subsets based on the type of respondent being examined and the source of the information. More information on the composition of each wave of the study and how to link data from different waves together can be found in the User Guide.</abstract>       <sumDscr>         <collDate>Wave One: 30 March - 19 October 2004.  Wave Two: 18 April - 18 September 2005. Wave Three: 21 April -  28 September 2006. Wave Four: 12 June - 14 October 2007. Wave Five: 3 June - 28 October 2008. Wave Six: 12 May - 14 October 2009. Wave Seven: 18 May - 12 October 2010.</collDate>         <nation>England</nation>         <geogUnit>Government Office Regions</geogUnit>         <anlyUnit>Individuals</anlyUnit>         <anlyUnit> Families/households</anlyUnit>         <universe>National</universe>         <universe>Young people in Year 9 (or equivalent) in schools in England in February 2004 (born between 1 September 1989 and 31 August 1990). For Waves One to Four, at least one of the young person's parents/guardians/carers were also interviewed. For Waves Five, Six and Seven, only the young person was interviewed. See documentation for further details.</universe>         <dataKind>Numeric data</dataKind>         <dataKind> Individual (micro) level</dataKind>       </sumDscr>     </stdyInfo>     <method>       <dataColl>         <timeMeth>Longitudinal/panel/cohort</timeMeth>         <timeMeth>Data from Waves One to Seven are included at present.</timeMeth>         <dataCollector>BMRB. Social Research</dataCollector>         <dataCollector>GfK NOP</dataCollector>         <dataCollector>Ipsos MORI</dataCollector>         <sampProc>Multi-stage stratified random sample</sampProc>         <sampProc>See documentation for further details.</sampProc>         <deviat>15,770 households at Wave One, 13,539 households at Wave Two, 12,439 households at Wave Three, 11,449 households (plus 352 households in ethnic boost sample) at Wave Four, 10,430 households at Wave Five, 9,799 households at Wave Six, and 8,682 households at Wave Seven.</deviat>         <collMode>Face-to-face interview; Telephone interview; Self-completion</collMode>         <collMode>For Waves One to Four, face-to-face interviews (with a self-completion element) were conducted; for Waves Five, Six and Seven, the young person could choose to complete the interview face-to-face, via telephone, or online (web-based).</collMode>         <sources />         <weight>Weighting used. See documentation for details.</weight>         <cleanOps>A*</cleanOps>       </dataColl>     </method>     <dataAccs>       <setAvail>         <accsPlac>UK Data Service</accsPlac>       </setAvail>       <useStmt>         <specPerm>Standard conditions of access</specPerm>         <restrctn>The depositor has specified that registration is required and standard conditions of use apply. The depositor may be informed about usage. See <a href=http://ukdataservice.ac.uk/get-data/how-to-access/conditions.aspx>terms and conditions of access</a> for further information.</restrctn>         <contact><a href=http://www.ukdataservice.ac.uk/help/get-in-touch.aspx>Get in touch</a></contact>         <conditions><i>Data Availability</i>:<br> The LSYPE Index and Household Grid files for Waves 1-4 are held at the UK Data Archive, but are subject to permission-only access. Users who require access to these files should contact the HelpDesk  in the first instance. Household Grid, Index and detailed Activity History* data for Waves 5-7 are not held at the Archive and an application for access should be made direct to the Longitudinal Studies Team at the Department for Education (DfE) - see the User Guide and the document 'LSYPE Confidentiality Form'. The decision to supply data will be made by the DfE on a case-by-case basis.<br> <br> *Categorised information on activity history is contained within the LSYPE Monthly Main Activity file for Waves 4 to 7 (file 'lsype_main_activity_w4-7_nov2011_suppressed'). See Section 5.8 of the User Guide for more information.</conditions>       </useStmt>     </dataAccs>     <othrStdyMat>       <relStdy>5677 Longitudinal Study of Young People in England; Wave 1, 2004: Teaching Dataset </relStdy>       <relStdy>6660 Statistical Regression Methods in Education Teaching Datasets: Longitudinal Study of Young People in England, 2004-2006 </relStdy>       <relStdy>7104 Longitudinal Study of Young People in England: Waves One to Seven, 2004-2010: Secure Access </relStdy>       <relPubl>Department for Education (2011) <i>Youth Cohort Study and Longitudinal Study of Young People in England: the activities and experiences of 19 year olds: England 2010</i>, Sheffield: Department for Education.
